title-group.article-title: Resting Energy Expenditure After Fontan Surgery in Children With Single-Ventricle Heart Defects

body.p: Mehta and colleagues1 describe a prospective cohort study to characterize the metabolic profile in the early postoperative period after cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in children undergoing Fontan surgery. These 26 children were enrolled in an unrelated clinical trial examining the effect of nesiritide and milrinone in the pediatric intensive care unit (PICU). The results address very relevant and timely conundrums in the PICU. They include the confirmation that indirect calorimetry (IC) measurements can be performed accurately in this population, which has been concluded previously by Mitchell et al,2 Avitzur et al,3 Li et al,4 and De Wit et al.5 Mehta also found that C-reactive protein (CRP) increases post-CPB but does not correlate with resting energy expenditure (REE) immediately in the postoperative period, illustrating that measuring CRP in the short term may not be helpful in prescribing energy. Most important, the measured REE (MREE) does not correlate with World Health Organization (WHO)6 equations postoperatively in Fontan children. Remarkably, the results showed that 73% of children were normometabolic or hypometabolic and, surprisingly, that 27% were hyper metabolic. The interpatient biovariability is impressive and is attributed to the acute phase response and the cascade of events that unfold dependent on the host body’s condition. The acute phase response in critically ill children is well described in numerous publications and commentaries by Walter Chwals.7-11 Of concern are the 27% of children who are hypermetabolic, attributed to higher lactates and more positive fluid balances requiring 60–77 kcal/kg/d. The practitioner has no extrapolation of knowledge to deal with the wide range of 37–77 kcal/kg/d in the absence of IC. The practical application of this information would translate to initiating enteral nutrition (EN) or parenteral nutrition (PN) within 24 hours post-CPB Fontan, at a mean REE of 57 ± 20 kcal/kg/d in the absence of IC. The consequence of this approach may lead to considerable over- and underfeeding based on the range that Mehta et al describe in this single population.

The prescription of metabolic support in the PICU is difficult as there is a need to illustrate clinical benefit to matching energy expenditure to energy prescription in this population of 3.6 ± 2.6 years. If the average mechanical ventilation duration is less than 24 hours, energy expenditure would be a moving target and would have to be reevaluated as the child would have greater caloric needs as ventilation is weaned. The questions are whether EN or PN is possible in the first 24 hours post-Fontan given the nil per os (NPO) periods for extubation and whether PN is necessary for that period. Many of these children are successfully extubated and would resume oral diets tolerated unless previously tube fed. Few studies have been able to demonstrate the benefits of matching energy expenditure to clinically relevant outcomes. Indeed, the optimal amount of energy intake during acute illness is a matter of recent debate and remains unclear. Both underfeeding and overfeeding are likely to impair outcomes and hence are not desirable in infants in the intensive care unit (ICU). Research is needed to properly address the underlying metabolism and growth, comorbidities, and preexisting energy reserve and the effects on long-term starvation in the ICU. Critically ill infants and children are at risk for nutrition deficiencies, altered nutrition status, and anthropometrics, leading to increased morbidity.

What is really being illustrated is that we cannot predict energy expenditure using clinical judgment, biochemistries, or predictive equations. True energy needs can only be determined by measuring energy expenditure with IC. This is confirmed in a recent Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition (JPEN) Original Communication by Kyle et al.12 As of yet, we have not yet been able to quantify hospital outcomes with caloric deficit. Furthermore, we have no means to measure the impact of over- or underfeeding in the PICU. Accurate assessment of energy expenditure allows optimal energy intake during the postoperative period, but does it change clinical outcomes such as length of ICU stay, days to chest closure, ventilation days, and total hospital days? How will the consequences of short-term nutrition deterioration and loss of muscle mass in the PICU be defined?
The timely JPEN article titled “Is Indirect Calorimetry a Necessity or a Luxury in the Pediatric Intensive Care Unit?” by Kyle et al clearly points to IC being a standard of care based on evidence.
This study is very relevant to current clinical work, the topic is current, and the results have the potential for changing clinical practice.
